channel.title: Interleaved RSS Feed
channel.description: This is an interleaved feed of the most recent entries from each RSS source, skipping any feeds with errors.

item.title: Postpartum PTSD: Right Diagnosis Can Help Mothers and Babies
item.description: Many new mothers aren’t aware that postpartum PTSD even exists, but it’s far from rare. Here's what to know.

item.title: The Sound of Freedom
item.description: For a million years (more like 15,) I’ve been listening to a radio show: The Taylor Strecker Show. It’s a daily show that originated on SiriusXM and through a series of events became an independently broadcasted show on Patreon. There’s something interesting that happens when you listen to a daily show. You get to know...Read More

item.title: So Many Nonstick Pans Have Forever Chemicals — This Is The Exception
item.description: Nonstick without the toxic coating.

item.title: Mayo Clinic Minute: Advances in minimally invasive kidney stone surgery
item.description: Most small kidney stones can pass on their own. However, kidney stones that are too large to pass on their own or cause bleeding, kidney damage or ongoing urinary tract infections may require surgical treatment. In this Mayo Clinic Minute, Dr. Aaron Potretzke, a Mayo Clinic urologist, explains some of the different surgical options for removing kidney stones. Watch: The Mayo Clinic […] The post Mayo Clinic Minute: Advances in minimally invasive kidney stone surgery appeared first on Mayo Clinic News Network.

item.title: Living With Major Depressive Disorder
item.description: See how one person manages the ups and downs of major depressive disorder -- and how her depression inspired her career as a therapist.

item.title: That Time I Went to the Eras Tour [Part Two]
item.description: To review part one of this adventure with Taylor Swift, click here. Click here to see all the Instagram highlight videos from Denver Night One. Mile High Stadium was pink and sparkly from head to toe. Never had I ever seen so many women in one place, nor so many generations piled into one venue. ...Read More

item.title: Noisy Neighbors Were Ruining My Sleep, Until I Found This Simple Hack
item.description: Relief from noisy neighbors.

item.title: Beyond weight loss: Bariatric surgery may reduce cancer risk
item.description: When you think about obesity, you may not connect it to cancer. However, researchers long have suspected a link between certain cancers and weight. Among those are endometrial, ovarian, colon, liver, pancreatic and postmenopausal breast cancers, which together contribute to 15 to 20% of all cancer deaths in the U.S. Cancer risk increases with obesity More than […] The post Beyond weight loss: Bariatric surgery may reduce cancer risk appeared first on Mayo Clinic News Network.

item.title: A Therapist’s Perspective
item.description: A therapist talks about managing major depressive disorder (MDD): what to expect, strategies for dealing with setbacks, and when to talk to your therapist.

item.title: That Time I Went to the Eras Tour [Part One]
item.description: Do you ever have one of those experiences where you want to remember exactly how you felt? That’s how I feel about my experience at the Taylor Swift concert this weekend. Correction: At the Eras Tour. Saying it was a concert does not feel like enough to justify the magnitude of the event. Let’s talk about the...Read More

item.title: The Secret To Overcoming Impostor Syndrome, From A Stanford Brain Surgeon
item.description: A Stanford brain surgeon explains.

item.title: Mayo Clinic Minute: Preventing pediatric falls
item.description: May is National Trauma Awareness Month. It's a time to spread awareness about injury prevention and trauma. Falls are the No. 1 cause of nonfatal injuries among children up to 14 years old in the U.S., according to the National Institutes of Health. Many of these pediatric falls happen at home or on the playground. […] The post Mayo Clinic Minute: Preventing pediatric falls appeared first on Mayo Clinic News Network.

item.title: Handling the Stigma
item.description: Learn from a mental health advocate how the stigma of depression is changing and how acceptance is the first step to managing major depressive disorder.

item.description: Special thanks to Jenny Craig for their sponsorship of this post. In honor of the Super Bowl this year, I decided to make a Philly to enjoy. Knowing the Philadelphia Eagles were playing (and with no plans to watch the game), I let the City of Brotherly Love inspire this tasty dish. I used the Jenny Craig...Read More

item.title: Here's How To Channel The Energy Of This Month's Powerful New Moon
item.description: It's in a grounding earth sign.

item.title: Electrospinning biotherapies of tomorrow
item.description: The future of healing disease may involve a syringe, a high voltage power supply and polymer solutions coming together to engineer tissue. Mayo Clinic researchers are studying these different elements now using an electrospinner, a device that whips biotherapeutic fibers into a scaffold — or platform — for spinning regenerative biotherapeutics. An electrospinner is almost […] The post Electrospinning biotherapies of tomorrow appeared first on Mayo Clinic News Network.

item.title: How I Share About My Condition
item.description: A person with major depressive disorder shares how they talk about their condition with others.

item.title: 3 Skin Care Facts This Aesthetics Specialist Wishes More People Knew
item.description: Today's guest on the Clean Beauty School podcast specializes not only in integrative medicine but also in the high-tech world of aesthetics.

item.title: Ovarian cancer: New treatments and research
item.description: Editor's note: May 8 is World Ovarian Cancer Day. Three cancers — ovarian epithelial cancer, fallopian tube cancer and primary peritoneal cancer — are commonly called ovarian cancer. They arise from the same kind of tissue and are treated similarly. "The ovaries and fallopian tubes are so anatomically close to each other that we sometimes can't […] The post Ovarian cancer: New treatments and research appeared first on Mayo Clinic News Network.
